questions.stem: Standard 3.05 (Multiple Relationships) states that a psychologist should avoid a multiple relationship if it could reasonably be expected to:

options.text: Create any form of social contact with a client outside the therapy office
Impair the psychologist's objectivity, competence, or effectiveness, or risk exploitation or harm
Involve any financial transaction between the psychologist and client
Lead to the client knowing personal details about the psychologist

questions.explanation: Standard 3.05 does not prohibit all multiple relationships. It states that psychologists refrain from entering a multiple relationship if it could reasonably be expected to impair objectivity, competence, or effectiveness, or risk exploitation of or harm to the person. Not all multiple relationships are avoidable (especially in small communities or military settings), and the standard acknowledges that not all multiple relationships are harmful. The key is the potential for impairment or exploitation.

questions.stem: Under Standard 3.10 (Informed Consent), when a psychologist provides services to a person who is legally incapable of giving informed consent, the psychologist should:

options.text: Decline to provide services until the person can provide consent
Provide an appropriate explanation, seek the individual's assent, and obtain permission from a legally authorized person
Obtain consent from any family member
Proceed without any form of consent since the person cannot legally consent

questions.explanation: Standard 3.10(b) requires that when persons are legally incapable of giving informed consent (e.g., minors, individuals with intellectual disabilities), psychologists provide an appropriate explanation, seek the individual's assent (agreement to participate to the extent they can understand), consider the person's preferences and best interests, and obtain appropriate permission from a legally authorized person (e.g., parent, guardian). Services should not simply be declined or provided without any consent process.

questions.stem: A psychologist serves as a consultant for a corporation and is asked by the CEO to evaluate an employee's fitness for a promotion. The employee was not informed of the evaluation's purpose. Under Standard 3.07 (Third-Party Requests for Services), the psychologist's primary obligation is to:

options.text: Conduct the evaluation as requested since the corporation is the paying client
Clarify the nature of the relationship with all parties, including the purpose and intended use of the evaluation, and inform the employee about the limits of confidentiality
Refuse the evaluation because it creates a multiple relationship
Conduct the evaluation but withhold findings from the corporation to protect the employee

questions.explanation: Standard 3.07 requires that when psychologists agree to provide services at the request of a third party, they must clarify at the outset the nature of the relationship with all individuals and organizations involved. This includes explaining who the client is, the probable uses of the information, and the limits of confidentiality. The employee must understand the evaluation's purpose, who will receive results, and what confidentiality protections (if any) apply. Proceeding without this clarity violates the standard, regardless of who pays for the service.

questions.stem: Standard 3.02 (Sexual Harassment) provides that psychologists do not engage in sexual harassment. A supervisee reports to the training director that their supervisor has been making repeated sexually suggestive comments during supervision meetings. According to Standard 3.02, which statement is most accurate?

options.text: The behavior is only sexual harassment if the supervisee experienced physical contact
Sexual harassment includes verbal conduct of a sexual nature that is sufficiently severe or pervasive, and the supervisor's behavior likely violates this standard
The supervisee's subjective discomfort is irrelevant if the supervisor did not intend to harass
The training director should wait for multiple formal complaints before acting

questions.explanation: Standard 3.02 defines sexual harassment as sexual solicitation, physical advances, or verbal or nonverbal conduct that is sexual in nature, when the conduct is sufficiently severe or intense to be abusive to a reasonable person in the context. The power differential inherent in the supervisor-supervisee relationship heightens the severity. Physical contact is not required; repeated sexually suggestive comments constitute verbal conduct of a sexual nature. The supervisor's intent is relevant but not determinative; the impact on the supervisee and the objective assessment of the conduct matter. Training programs have an obligation to respond promptly to reports.

questions.stem: A psychologist has been treating a client for six months. The client's attorney contacts the psychologist and requests that the psychologist also serve as an expert witness regarding the client's psychological damages in a civil lawsuit. Under Standard 3.05, the psychologist should:

options.text: Agree, since the psychologist has the most knowledge of the client's condition
Recognize that serving as both treating clinician and forensic evaluator creates a multiple relationship with significant potential for impaired objectivity, and decline the forensic role
Agree only if the client signs a consent form
Agree but limit testimony to factual treatment information without offering expert opinions

questions.explanation: Serving as both treating therapist and forensic expert for the same client creates a problematic multiple relationship under Standard 3.05. The therapeutic role involves advocacy and alliance with the client, while the forensic role demands impartiality and objective evaluation. These roles have fundamentally different goals, methodologies, and allegiances. APA guidelines on forensic practice explicitly warn against this dual role. While the psychologist may be subpoenaed to provide factual testimony about treatment, actively taking on the expert witness role would impair professional objectivity and potentially compromise both the treatment relationship and forensic conclusions.

questions.stem: According to Standard 3.04 (Avoiding Harm), which of the following actions would be consistent with this standard? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Taking reasonable steps to avoid harming clients and others with whom one works
Minimizing harm where it is foreseeable and unavoidable
Not using techniques known to be harmful simply because they are popular
Avoiding all risk of negative outcomes in therapy
Considering the potential impact of professional actions on vulnerable populations

questions.explanation: Standard 3.04 requires psychologists to take reasonable steps to avoid harming those with whom they work and to minimize unavoidable harm. This includes avoiding known harmful techniques (C) and considering impacts on vulnerable populations (E). However, the standard recognizes that some risk of negative outcomes is inherent in professional practice (D is unrealistic and not required). The standard sets a reasonable, not absolute, standard of care.

questions.stem: Under Standard 3.10 (Informed Consent), the informed consent process for psychological services should include which elements? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: The nature and anticipated course of therapy
Fees and billing arrangements
The limits of confidentiality
A guarantee of specific treatment outcomes
The client's right to refuse or withdraw from treatment

questions.explanation: Informed consent should include: nature of services (A), fees (B), limits of confidentiality (C, also required by Standard 4.02), and the right to refuse or withdraw (E). Guaranteeing outcomes (D) would actually be an ethical violation because it is misleading. Informed consent is an ongoing process, not a one-time event, and should be documented. Additional elements may include qualifications, alternative treatments, and potential risks and benefits.

questions.stem: Which of the following situations involve a multiple relationship as defined by Standard 3.05? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: A psychologist provides therapy to their graduate student
A psychologist in a small town encounters a client at the grocery store
A psychologist enters a business partnership with a current therapy client
A psychologist begins a romantic relationship with a former supervisee
A psychologist provides therapy to the spouse of a current client

questions.explanation: Multiple relationships exist when a psychologist is in a professional role with a person and simultaneously has another relationship with the same person (or a closely associated person). Therapy with one's student (A), business with a client (C), romantic relationship with former supervisee (D), and treating a current client's spouse (E) are all multiple relationships. Incidental contact at a grocery store (B) is not a relationshipâ€”it is a chance encounter and does not constitute a multiple relationship.

questions.stem: Standard 3.05 (Multiple Relationships) of the APA Ethics Code addresses situations where a psychologist is in a professional role with a person and simultaneously has another relationship with that person. Which of the following scenarios represent problematic multiple relationships? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: A psychologist provides therapy to a client and also serves as an expert witness evaluating that same client's competency in a legal proceeding
A psychologist sees a client for therapy and later encounters the client at a large community event where they exchange brief pleasantries
A psychologist provides individual therapy to one member of a couple while simultaneously conducting custody evaluation of the same couple
A psychologist who is the only provider in a rural area treats a client who is also a fellow member of the local parent-teacher organization
A psychologist agrees to provide therapy to an employee who reports directly to the psychologist's spouse

questions.explanation: Standard 3.05 states that a multiple relationship occurs when a psychologist is in a professional role with a person and simultaneously is in another relationship with that person (or someone closely associated). Problematic multiple relationships are those that could reasonably impair objectivity, competence, or effectiveness, or risk exploitation or harm. Serving as both therapist and forensic evaluator (A) creates a direct conflict between advocacy and objectivity. Providing therapy to one party while evaluating the couple in custody (C) creates divided loyalties. Treating someone who reports to your spouse (E) creates a problematic entanglement. Brief incidental contact (B) is not a multiple relationship. The APA Ethics Code acknowledges that in small communities (D), some role overlap may be unavoidable, and the key issue is whether it impairs professional judgment.

questions.stem: Under Standard 3.08 (Exploitative Relationships), which of the following constitute exploitation of persons over whom psychologists have authority? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: A supervisor requiring supervisees to purchase the supervisor's textbook at full price as a condition of supervision
A professor recommending their own textbook when it is the most relevant resource for the course
A psychologist pressuring a client to invest in the psychologist's personal business venture
A supervisor requiring a supervisee to provide free child care in exchange for favorable evaluations
A psychologist using a client's professional network to secure personal consulting contracts

questions.explanation: Standard 3.08 prohibits psychologists from exploiting persons over whom they have supervisory, evaluative, or other authority, such as clients, students, supervisees, research participants, and employees. Requiring textbook purchases as a condition of supervision (A), pressuring client investment in personal ventures (C), demanding personal services for favorable evaluations (D), and leveraging a client's network for personal gain (E) all exploit the power differential. Recommending one's own relevant textbook (B) is acceptable professional practice when the text is genuinely the best resource, as long as the recommendation is not coercive.

questions.stem: Match each type of multiple relationship to its correct description under the APA Ethics Code:

rows.text: Potentially harmful multiple relationship requiring careful evaluation

columns.text: Psychologist sees a client at a community event and briefly exchanges greetings
Psychologist in a small rural town treats the only available mechanic in the area
Psychologist enters a sexual relationship with a current therapy client
Psychologist is invited to serve on a board with a former client

questions.explanation: Sexual relationships with current clients (col3) are always prohibited under Standard 10.05. Rural practice may create unavoidable dual relationships (col2) that must be managed with clear boundaries and documentation. Brief incidental contact (col1) is not a multiple relationship. Serving on a board with a former client (col4) requires careful evaluation of potential risks to objectivity and the former client's welfare.

questions.stem: Match each clinical scenario to the Standard 3 provision most directly implicated:

rows.text: A psychologist conducts a custody evaluation at the request of one parent's attorney without informing the other parent
A psychology professor offers extra credit to students who participate in the professor's research study, with no alternative extra credit option
A psychologist continues using a confrontational treatment approach after the client repeatedly reports feeling emotionally harmed
A psychologist begins a sexual relationship with a current supervisee

questions.explanation: Conducting a custody evaluation at one attorney's request without informing the other parent creates a conflict of interest (3.06) because the psychologist is being retained by one side in an adversarial proceeding. Offering research participation for extra credit without alternatives raises informed consent issues (3.10) because students may feel coerced. Continuing harmful treatment despite client reports violates avoiding harm (3.04). A sexual relationship with a current supervisee creates a prohibited multiple relationship (3.05) due to the power differential.

questions.stem: For each Standard 3 provision, select ALL actions that would constitute a violation:

columns.text: Using conversion therapy on a minor despite evidence of harm
Hiring a current client as an office assistant
Pressuring a supervisee to purchase the supervisor's book
Conducting therapy with a student one is currently grading
Using a client's personal connections for business opportunities

questions.explanation: Standard 3.04 violation: Using conversion therapy despite known harm (col1). Standard 3.05 violations: Hiring a client as an employee (col2) and providing therapy to a student being graded (col4) are both multiple relationships with clear potential for impairment of objectivity. Standard 3.08 violations: Pressuring a supervisee to purchase products (col3) and using client connections for business (col5) exploit the professional relationship for personal gain.

questions.stem: For each type of professional relationship, select ALL Standard 3 provisions that impose specific obligations on the psychologist:

columns.text: Standard 3.11: Psychological Services Delivered To or Through Organizations

questions.explanation: Supervisory relationships implicate Standard 3.05 (avoiding multiple relationships with supervisees) and Standard 3.08 (not exploiting the authority inherent in supervision). Organizational consulting implicates Standard 3.07 (clarifying roles when third parties request services) and Standard 3.11 (obligations when services are delivered through organizations, including informing about roles and confidentiality limits). Court-ordered treatment implicates Standard 3.07 (the court is a third party requesting services) and Standard 3.10 (informed consent must still be obtained even in mandated treatment, or limits must be explained).

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about Standard 3.05 (Multiple Relationships):

A multiple relationship occurs when a psychologist is in a [BLANK1] role with a person and at the same time is in another role with that person, or with a person [BLANK2] to that person. Multiple relationships that would not reasonably be expected to cause impairment or risk [BLANK3] are not unethical. In small communities, psychologists may face [BLANK4] multiple relationships and must take reasonable steps to manage them. If a psychologist finds that a harmful multiple relationship has arisen, they should attempt to resolve it with [BLANK5] to the affected person.

options: due regard for the best interests of
BLANK5.correct: due regard for the best interests of

questions.explanation: Standard 3.05 defines a multiple relationship as having a professional role alongside another relationship with the same person or a closely associated person. The standard is nuanced: not all multiple relationships are prohibited, only those risking impairment or exploitation/harm. In small communities, some are unavoidable. When harmful multiple relationships arise, resolution should prioritize the affected person's best interests.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about Standard 3.04 and Standard 3.08:

Standard 3.04 (Avoiding Harm) requires psychologists to take [BLANK1] steps to avoid harming clients, supervisees, and others with whom they work. When harm is [BLANK2] and unavoidable, psychologists must take steps to minimize it. Standard 3.08 (Exploitative Relationships) specifically prohibits psychologists from exploiting persons over whom they have [BLANK3] authority. This includes not engaging in relationships that could be exploitative due to the [BLANK4] inherent in the professional role. When a psychologist becomes aware that a professional action has caused unintended harm, Standard 3.04 requires the psychologist to [BLANK5] the harm rather than ignore it.
questions.explanation: Standard 3.04 uses the 'reasonable steps' standard, recognizing that harm cannot always be eliminated but must be minimized when foreseeable. Standard 3.08 addresses exploitation across all relationships where psychologists hold supervisory, evaluative, or other authority, recognizing the power differential inherent in professional roles. When unintended harm occurs, the ethical response is mitigation, not avoidance or denial.

questions.stem: A psychologist in a rural community of 2,000 people is providing therapy to a farmer for depression. The psychologist's only reliable car mechanic in the area is this same farmer. The psychologist's car breaks down and needs immediate repair to get to work.
questions.centerQuestion: What ethical standard is most relevant to this situation?

options.text: Financial transaction creates a secondary relationship
Power differential in the therapy relationship could affect the business interaction
Small community means this dual relationship is widely observable
The psychologist has many other mechanic options available
Discuss the dual relationship openly with the client and document the discussion
Maintain clear boundaries between the therapy and business relationships
Immediately terminate therapy to eliminate the dual relationship
Monitor for any impact of the dual relationship on therapy

questions.explanation: This is a classic Standard 3.05 rural practice dilemma. The multiple relationship is largely unavoidable in a small community. Risk factors include the financial transaction, power differential, and community visibility. Appropriate management includes open discussion, clear boundaries, and ongoing monitoring. Immediate termination would actually harm the client by denying access to mental health services in a rural area. The Ethics Code recognizes that not all multiple relationships are harmful and that management rather than avoidance may be appropriate.

questions.stem: A psychologist in a small rural community discovers that a new client referred for anxiety treatment is the parent of a child the psychologist has been evaluating for a learning disability at the local school. The psychologist is the only licensed mental health provider within a 90-mile radius.
questions.centerQuestion: What is the most relevant ethical standard governing this situation?

options.text: The dual role creates a risk of impaired objectivity in the child's evaluation
Information from therapy could inadvertently influence the educational assessment
There are no alternative providers available in the geographic area
The psychologist's income depends on accepting all available referrals
Refuse to treat the parent under all circumstances to avoid any dual relationship
Document the potential conflict and take steps to minimize risk of harm
Establish clear boundaries regarding what information can be shared between the two professional roles
Consult with a colleague about managing the multiple relationship

questions.explanation: Standard 3.05 (Multiple Relationships) is the governing standard. It states that a multiple relationship is not necessarily unethical if it would not reasonably be expected to cause impairment or risk exploitation. The APA Ethics Code recognizes that in small communities, avoiding all multiple relationships may not be feasible. Complicating factors include objectivity risk, information contamination, and limited alternatives. Financial motivation is not an ethical complicating factor in this context. Appropriate actions include documenting the situation, establishing clear role boundaries, and consulting with colleagues. Categorically refusing all services would be overly rigid and could deprive the client of needed care, which the Ethics Code does not require.

questions.stem: A psychologist is reviewing Standard 3 (Human Relations) with a supervisee. Highlight the FOUR accurate statements:
questions.passage: (A) Standard 3.01 prohibits unfair discrimination based on age, gender, race, ethnicity, and other protected characteristics. (B) Multiple relationships are always unethical and must be avoided in all circumstances. (C) Standard 3.04 requires psychologists to take reasonable steps to avoid harming those with whom they work. (D) Psychologists may engage in sexual harassment if the other person appears to consent. (E) Standard 3.08 prohibits psychologists from exploiting persons over whom they have supervisory, evaluative, or other authority. (F) Informed consent must be obtained only when providing therapy, not for assessment or research. (G) Standard 3.06 prohibits psychologists from offering inducements that are likely to coerce participation. (H) Psychologists must refuse to work in any setting where multiple relationships might arise.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (A) Standard 3.01 prohibits unfair discrimination; (C) Standard 3.04 addresses avoiding harm; (E) Standard 3.08 prohibits exploitation; (G) Standard 3.06 addresses improper inducements. Incorrect: (B) Multiple relationships are not always unethical; (D) Sexual harassment is always prohibited (3.02); (F) Informed consent applies to therapy, assessment, and research (3.10); (H) The Code acknowledges unavoidable multiple relationships and requires management, not avoidance of all settings.

questions.stem: A licensing board investigator is reviewing case files for Standard 3 compliance. Highlight the FOUR scenarios that represent clear Standard 3 violations:
questions.passage: (A) A psychologist in a small town encounters a client at a community fundraiser and exchanges brief pleasantries before moving on. (B) A psychologist conducts custody evaluations for both parents in a divorce case while simultaneously providing individual therapy to one parent. (C) A training director begins a sexual relationship with a current doctoral intern in the program. (D) A supervisor provides constructive feedback to a supervisee about areas for clinical improvement, which the supervisee finds upsetting. (E) A psychologist accepts a referral from a colleague who specializes in a different area and provides appropriate treatment. (F) A psychologist threatens to terminate a client's therapy unless the client agrees to participate in the psychologist's research study. (G) A neuropsychologist hires a current therapy client to serve as the office receptionist, where the client will have access to other patients' scheduling information. (H) A psychologist provides pro bono services to a client who cannot afford the standard fee.
questions.explanation: (B) Conducting custody evaluation for both parents while treating one parent violates Standard 3.05 (multiple relationships with conflicting roles). (C) A sexual relationship with a current intern violates Standards 3.02/3.05/7.07 (power differential, exploitation, prohibited sexual relationship). (F) Threatening termination to coerce research participation violates Standard 3.04 (avoiding harm) and 3.08 (exploitation). (G) Hiring a therapy client as receptionist creates a clearly harmful multiple relationship under 3.05 and risks confidentiality breaches. (A) is incidental contact, not a violation. (D) is appropriate supervision. (E) and (H) are ethical practices.

questions.stem: Arrange the elements of informed consent in the order they should typically be addressed during the initial session:

options.text: Discuss the client's right to refuse or withdraw from treatment at any time
Explain the nature of the proposed services and treatment approach
Obtain the client's signature on the informed consent document
Discuss fees, billing practices, and insurance arrangements
Review the limits of confidentiality including mandatory reporting obligations

questions.explanation: Informed consent should flow logically: Begin by explaining what services will be provided (nature of therapy, approach). Then discuss confidentiality limits so the client understands the parameters of the relationship. Address practical matters like fees and billing. Ensure the client knows they can refuse or withdraw at any time. Finally, obtain the documented consent. This order moves from understanding the service to understanding rights, with documentation last.

questions.stem: Arrange the steps a psychologist should take when an unavoidable multiple relationship arises in a rural practice setting, in the correct order:

options.text: Consult with a colleague or ethics committee about the situation
Identify and document the nature of the multiple relationship and potential risks
Continuously monitor for signs that the dual relationship is affecting professional judgment or the client's welfare
Discuss the situation transparently with the client, including potential risks and management strategies
Establish and document clear boundaries to minimize risk of impairment or exploitation

questions.explanation: The proper sequence for managing an unavoidable rural multiple relationship: First, identify and document the dual relationship and its potential risks. Consult with a colleague to get an objective perspective. Then discuss the situation transparently with the client, as the client has a right to understand the nature of the relationship and potential impacts. Establish clear boundaries with documentation. Finally, continuously monitor the situation, as the impact of a multiple relationship can emerge or change over time. This process reflects the APA Ethics Code's recognition that multiple relationships in rural settings require management rather than categorical avoidance.

questions.stem: A university counseling center tracks the types of Standard 3 (Human Relations) challenges encountered by its psychologists over 5 years:

datasets.name: Informed consent challenges with mandated clients (%)

questions.question: Which category of Standard 3 challenge showed the most consistent upward trend?

options.text: Multiple relationship concerns
Informed consent challenges
Third-party request conflicts
All categories increased at the same rate

questions.question: What likely explains the increasing third-party request conflicts?

options.text: Psychologists are becoming less competent at managing these requests
Growing institutional pressure on counseling centers to serve administrative and athletic department needs creates Standard 3.07 tensions
Students are making fewer self-referrals
The APA Ethics Code was revised to create more third-party obligations

questions.explanation: Third-party request conflicts showed the steepest and most consistent increase (10% to 26%, a 16-point increase), reflecting growing institutional pressures on university counseling centers. Athletic departments, academic affairs, and student conduct offices increasingly request psychological information or services, creating Standard 3.07 tensions about who the client is and how information will be used. Multiple relationship concerns fluctuated slightly (22% to 32%), reflecting the inherent challenge of avoiding dual roles in campus communities. Informed consent challenges with mandated clients (18% to 28%) increased as more students are referred through conduct or Title IX processes.

questions.stem: A state ethics committee analyzes complaints related to Standard 3.05 (Multiple Relationships) across different practice settings over 6 years:

questions.question: What does the shift in complaint sources suggest about the evolving nature of multiple relationship challenges?

options.text: Rural psychologists have become more ethical than urban psychologists
Digital and social media interactions are creating a new category of boundary challenges that the profession is still learning to navigate
Multiple relationship concerns are declining overall
Urban psychologists are relocating to rural areas

questions.question: What proactive step would be most appropriate to address the online/social media trend?

options.text: Prohibit all psychologists from using social media
Develop specific training and guidelines for managing digital boundaries and applying Standard 3.05 to online interactions
Ignore the trend since social media is not covered by the Ethics Code
Reduce the number of ethics complaints accepted about social media

questions.explanation: The dramatic rise in online/social media boundary complaints (8% to 36%) reflects the emergence of digital interactions as a major source of multiple relationship challenges. Clients discovering psychologists' personal social media, friend/follow requests, online reviews, and digital communication outside sessions create novel boundary issues that Standard 3.05 was not specifically written to address. The decline in both rural and traditional urban complaints may reflect better training and awareness in those areas. The profession needs targeted training and guidelines for applying existing ethical principles to digital contexts.

questions.stem: Categorize each scenario as either a problematic multiple relationship or an acceptable/manageable professional situation:

categories.label: Acceptable or Manageable Situation (Does Not Violate Standard 3.05)

items.text: Providing therapy to an employee whom you supervise at work
A rural psychologist attending the same community church as a client
Accepting a client's offer of free legal services in exchange for reduced therapy fees
Providing mandated crisis debriefing to a colleague after a workplace critical incident
Entering a business partnership with a current therapy client
Serving on a dissertation committee for a student whom you treated years ago for a brief, resolved issue

questions.explanation: Problematic: Therapy with a supervised employee (item1) involves a power differential; bartering services (item3) creates financial entanglement and exploitation risk; business partnership with a client (item5) creates conflicting interests. Acceptable/manageable: Attending the same church in a rural area (item2) is an unavoidable incidental contact; mandated crisis debriefing for a colleague (item4) is a limited, one-time professional service; serving on a committee for a former client treated briefly years ago (item6) carries minimal risk if the former treatment was brief and resolved.

questions.stem: Categorize each obligation according to the specific Standard 3 provision it falls under:

items.text: Explaining the purpose and nature of a court-ordered evaluation to the individual being evaluated
Minimizing foreseeable and unavoidable harm to clients during the course of treatment
Clarifying the role of the psychologist and intended use of findings when hired by an attorney
Obtaining assent from a minor who cannot legally consent to treatment
Refraining from using therapeutic techniques known to cause psychological harm
Informing the individual that an employer-requested fitness-for-duty evaluation may not be confidential

questions.explanation: Standard 3.04 (Avoiding Harm) encompasses minimizing unavoidable harm and refraining from known harmful techniques. Standard 3.07 (Third-Party Requests) addresses clarifying roles when an attorney or employer requests services, including informing individuals about how the information will be used and confidentiality limits. Standard 3.10 (Informed Consent) covers explaining the purpose of evaluations (including court-ordered ones) and obtaining assent from minors who cannot legally consent. Note that court-ordered and employer-requested situations involve overlap between Standards 3.07 and 3.10.
